block.p: ROCKAWAY PARK The Vikings Are Coming

Some 1,000 years after Leif Ericson arrived in America, several Viking ship replicas will sail into Jamaica Bay today. Among them will be the Viking Plym, which was hand-carved in 1912 and is the oldest Viking replica still sailing. The Skid bladner, the largest Viking replica, is also expected for the event, called Rockaway Viking Sail 2000 and coordinated by the Rockaway Chamber of Commerce.

Gabriel Popian, with his wife, Lucia, and their son John, artists from Romania, have contributed a movable sculpture that commemorates the return of the ships, using several elements of Viking decoration.

Among them will be the Viking Plym, which was hand-carved in 1912 and is the oldest Viking replica still sailing. Gabriel Popian, with his wife, Lucia, and their son John, artists from Romania, have contributed a movable sculpture that commemorates the return of the ships, using several elements of Viking decoration.
There will be live music, children's arts and crafts, food vendors, a Cherokee powwow and a fireworks display.
Rockaway Viking Sail 2000 today noon to 9 p.m.; Beach 116th Street and Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Park; free; (718) 945-5738.
CLINTON Tugging for Glory At a Race on the Hudson

It isn't a holiday weekend for the hard-working tugboats of the Hudson. More than 12 tugs (some of them shown below) will gather today at the Intrepid Museum to race in the Eighth Annual Tugboat Challenge.

There will also be a spinach-eating contest, a parade of tugs led with a water display from a Fire Department boat, a line-throwing competition and awards. Theodore Tugboat, a PBS character, will lead the day's events, which can be viewed from the flight deck at the Intrepid or from the spectator barge.

The Eighth Annual Tugboat Challenge; today 12:30 to 4 p.m.; the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum, Pier 86 (West 46th Street at 12th Avenue); $12; students, people over 65 and veterans, $9; children 6 to 11, $6; children 2 to 5, $2; children under 2, museum members and people on active duty in the United States military, free; (212) 957-7055.
WASHINGTON SQUARE Art From Wall to Curb In the Village Like No Other

You can stroll the sidewalks of Greenwich Village as they are transformed into a treasure trove during the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit this weekend and next. This exhibition has been part of the art scene since 1931, and has helped to introduce artists like Pollock and De Kooning.
This year, 200 artists are exhibiting over 20 city blocks that border Washington Square Park. Participants are both veterans and newcomers, whose work was approved by a selection jury.
More than 50 prizes will be awarded on Saturday in categories like pastels, watercolors, mixed media and crafts. (A scene from the spring show is below.)

Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit; today, tomorrow, Saturday and next Sunday , noon to 6 p.m.; in and around Washington Square; free; for more information and a copy of the exhibit map, (212) 982-6255.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

CHELSEA SALSA -- Freddie Dejesus leads the band Conjuto Placer, an eight-piece Latin ensemble, to kick off the Kitchen Neighborhood Street Fair on Saturday. There will also be swing music, a puppet show, interactive workshops, walking tours and talks in Chelsea art galleries; 2 to 5 p.m.; 19th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues; free; (212) 255-5793, ext. 13.

LATIN AT THE GARDEN -- Fiesta de Jardines, a Latin American celebration at the New York Botanical Garden, features live music and dance, a tropical market, puppet shows and storytelling sessions; Saturday and next Sunday; New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street; most events are free with garden admission: adults, $10; students and people over 65, $7.50; ages 2 to 12, $4; (718) 817-8700.

NATURE ON THE WING -- Visitors can wander through woods and wetlands to spot gulls, terns, swallows and sparrows at Great Kills Park in a walk led by Cliff Hagen, a naturalist affiliated with the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences; next Sunday 9:30 a.m.; meet in the parking lot across from the park's administration building, Buffalo Street and Hylan Boulevard; free; (718) 727-1135.
